<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 299, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 354, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A ball of mass \(130 \text{g}\) is launched from the ground at an initial velocity of \(14 \text{m/s}\) vertically upwards. It decelerates until it is at rest momentarily at a height \(h\) above the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 324, 136]]<|/det|>
Define deceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 209, 146, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 209, 482, 228]]<|/det|>
The acceleration of free fall is \(9.8 \text{m/s}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
Show that the time taken for the ball to reach height \(h\) is 1.4 s. Ignore the effect of air resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 397, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 537, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 146, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 561, 662]]<|/det|>
The ball is dropped from the top of a tall building.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 674, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
Describe and explain the motion of the ball as it falls. Consider the effect of air resistance in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 146, 444]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 425, 574, 444]]<|/det|>
The two lights in Fig. 2.1 are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 456, 687, 475]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 543, 895, 562]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows two children balanced on a seesaw. A seesaw is a length of wood which rotates about a central pivot.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 112, 764, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 345, 532, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 376, 144, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 376, 579, 395]]<|/det|>
Child B moves \(0.050 \text{m}\) further away from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 181, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 408, 547, 426]]<|/det|>
Explain why the seesaw rotates clockwise.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 500, 180, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 680, 518]]<|/det|>
Child A puts on a backpack and the seesaw now balances.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 530, 495, 549]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass of the backpack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 747, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<form>mass = .................................................... $kg$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 747, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The concrete floor under the seesaw is replaced with a rubber floor. A child falls from the seesaw and experiences an impulse when they hit the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 183, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 117, 326, 135]]<|/det|>
Define impulse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 181, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 648, 228]]<|/det|>
Explain how the rubber floor reduces injury to the child.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 761, 243]]<|/det|>
Use ideas about impulse, force, momentum and time in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 351, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows a stainless-steel saucepan being heated on an electric cooker. The saucepan contains water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 112, 670, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 305, 532, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 338, 146, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 337, 801, 356]]<|/det|>
State what happens to the water particles as the water temperature increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 367, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 146, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
The saucepan contains \(250 \text{cm}^3\) of water. The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 180, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 446, 685, 465]]<|/det|>
Show that the mass of the water in the saucepan is \(0.25 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 630, 181, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 630, 890, 648]]<|/det|>
Calculate the energy required to increase the water temperature from \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(65^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 817, 922, 835]]<|/det|>
<form>energy = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 688, 89]]<|/det|>
The heater supplies enough power to heat the water in 39 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 87, 702, 104]]<|/det|>
A student measures the time taken to heat the water as 115 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
Suggest why the actual time taken to heat the water is longer. Assume that the student takes accurate measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 144, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 918, 259]]<|/det|>
The stainless-steel saucepan is replaced with an aluminium saucepan of the same mass. It contains the same volume of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 650, 291]]<|/det|>
The specific heat capacity of stainless steel is \(500 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \degree \text{C})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 620, 306]]<|/det|>
The specific heat capacity of aluminium is \(890 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \degree \text{C})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 860, 337]]<|/det|>
Explain how using an aluminium saucepan will affect the time taken to heat the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 584, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.1 shows two containers, each filled with hot water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 97, 727, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 230, 532, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 261, 504, 280]]<|/det|>
The outer surface of the metal container is hot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 146, 311]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 824, 311]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 146, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 757, 512]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 587, 920, 620]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Fig. 7.1 shows two charged metal plates. X marks the position of the centre of the space between the plates.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 272, 532, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 7.1, draw at least **four** field lines to show the pattern and the direction of the electric field between the two charged plates. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 349, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 349, 722, 368]]<|/det|>

<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 409, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 148, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
During a thunderstorm, an electric field is set up between a cloud and the ground. Charges on the cloud and on the ground are shown in Fig. 7.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 483, 656, 655]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 675, 534, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 706, 781, 725]]<|/det|>
The lightning shown in Fig. 7.2 discharges a current of 28 000 A for 0.0012 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 738, 181, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 738, 693, 757]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 892, 920, 911]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 559, 89]]<|/det|>
The lightning transfers \(1.2 \times 10^{8} \text{J}\) of energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 855, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the potential difference between the base of the cloud and the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>potential difference = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 838, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 9.1 shows a mobile phone (cell phone) being charged on a wireless charging plate.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 97, 752, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 234, 532, 253]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 9.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 146, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 265, 918, 299]]<|/det|>
When the charging plate is switched on, there is an alternating current (a.c.) in the primary coil. A secondary coil is in the mobile phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 618, 330]]<|/det|>
Explain how a current is produced in the secondary coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 146, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 792, 454]]<|/det|>
The maximum energy stored in the battery of the mobile phone is \(0.012 \text{kWh}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 180, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 576, 486]]<|/det|>
Show that this maximum energy is \(4.3 \times 10^{4} \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 591, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 180, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 621, 725, 640]]<|/det|>
The charging plate in Fig. 9.1 has a useful output power of \(15 \text{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
The phone manufacturer claims that the battery can be charged to \(50\%\) capacity in less than 30 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 683, 423, 701]]<|/det|>
Show that this claim is true.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 888]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 901, 920, 918]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Leaks in underground water pipes are detected using radioactive tracers. Fig. 10.1 shows a radiation detector above a water pipe.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 112, 707, 457]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 472, 537, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 144, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
Before the radioactive tracer is added to the water, the detector measures the background radiation above the pipe. The average background radiation is 26 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 181, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 549, 435, 567]]<|/det|>
Define background radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 643, 183, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 643, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
Suggest one source of radiation that may make a significant contribution to the background count rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
